unit_learning_outcomes.description: Identify key stakeholders, actors and structures in the field of Security Studies.
Apply Security Studies’ key approaches, theories, concepts to both historical and current events in order to gain insight and understanding.
Demonstrate understanding of key approaches, theories, concepts, issues and debates in Security Studies.
Model basic academic skills, in particular, being able to demonstrate analytical reading and annotation skills.
Develop oral and written communication skills

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Students will be expected to be prepared to actively participate in either the tutorial or online forums by completing the weekly reading and attending/watching the lecture

assessments.description: Students will write an analytical essay that applies a leading approach or theory in security studies to a case study
Students will be expected to actively engage in the weekly discussions and debates within their tutorials (on campus students) or on the iLearn discussion forums (fully online students).
Students will annotate the required readings.

data.unit_offering_text:
Session 1, Fully online/virtual
Session 1, Weekday attendance, North Ryde
Session 1, Special circumstances

academic_org.value: Department of Security Studies and Criminology

data.description: This unit is a gateway unit into further study in Security Studies. It will introduce students to the theoretical foundations, essential concepts and central issues in the field of Security Studies. It will also further develop and refine students’ academic skills and literacy. Students will learn how to use Security Studies' central theories and concepts to gain a deeper understanding of the leading security challenges currently confronting Australia and the wider world. At its conclusion, students will have acquired the academic skills and conceptual knowledge necessary to successfully pursue their undergraduate studies in Security Studies.
data.title: Introduction to Security Studies
